It was useless to try and talk to Lord Elder on the other end, having heard=
 the static that was coming over his radio com link.  Instead, Tucson conce=
ntrates on getting everyone out of there in one piece.  Runing from the thr=
eat gave them a jump ahead of the enemy, but only for so long, could they c=
ontinue this way, without runing out of energy.  Something needed to be don=
e.  Tucson had to prove himself a worthy leader, and if he was going to do =
so, now was the time to prove it.  Perhaps the dragon would have known how =
to protect his kingdom from destruction, but how did he protect it without =
technology to aid him?  He could not breathe fire, so that was out of the q=
uestion.  But fire had to be born of a higher element.  Lightning.  Lightni=
ng, when it strikes the ground, it can create fire.  And following lightnin=
g, comes the rain that falls to the ground, snuffing the flames of destruct=
ion.  His voice, when he roars, he sounds like thunder, so would it stand t=
o reason that maybe there could be something else in his breath, that he ha=
d not explored yet.  

" Voice, like thunder, loud enough to rattle the gro=
und.. Thunder..  After thunder, comes rain.  But before all that, comes lig=
htning.  Cast to the sky from the ground up..  Lightning causes fire, but i=
t can also take it away."

He looks to everyone, being sure no one is withi=
n his radius.  He opens his mouth and concentrates.  Tiny bolts of lightnin=
g begin to come up from his gullet and crackle out from his mouth.  He then=
 roars, as it sounds like thunder, rumbling across the ground.  

"I know w=
hat I must do."

While emerging out near the top of the mountain, Tucson sp=
reads his wings, and beats them to lift himself upward into the smoke fille=
d sky.  It takes him great effort but he slowly starts lifting off the side=
 of the mountain and into the air.  He now attempts to create enough static=
 electricity to induce stormcloud formation.  If he could get it to rain, b=
y using that science and the power of the old dragon, he could at least sta=
ll the magma enough to get everyone out of there in decent shape, and stop =
the firey bird above.  Yet, he was exhausted.  Could he do this now, in his=
 physical state?  He had to try.  With great determination, dead set in his=
 eyes, the dragon now picks up his speed in the air, and flies after the bi=
rd.

" Not this time, Magmatron, not this time!"

He opens wide, and concen=
trates with all his might, to breathe a bolt of lightning, just strong enou=
gh to attempt stormcloud formation and hopefully a little rainstorm along w=
ith it.
